head.title: Man Given 4 Years Under New Jersey Hate Crimes Law for 1999 Incident

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Man Given 4 Years Under New Jersey Hate Crimes Law for 1999 Incident

abstract.p: man given 4 years under new jersey ha

block.p: In a ruling that reassured anti-discrimination groups concerned that a recent Supreme Court decision would weaken New Jersey's hate crimes law, a state Superior Court judge today imposed a strict sentence on a man who had pleaded guilty to an anti-Semitic rock-throwing spree in a heavily Jewish section of the city.
This was the first bias crime case to reach a state court since the Supreme Court last month limited judges' sentencing discretion in such cases.

In a ruling that reassured anti-discrimination groups concerned that a recent Supreme Court decision would weaken New Jersey's hate crimes law, a state Superior Court judge today imposed a strict sentence on a man who had pleaded guilty to an anti-Semitic rock-throwing spree in a heavily Jewish section of the city.
This was the first bias crime case to reach a state court since the Supreme Court last month limited judges' sentencing discretion in such cases.
The defendant, Michael Melchione, was given four years in prison, with no chance of parole until two years had been served.
The sentence, according to prosecutors, hinged on an admission by Mr. Melchione, 35, of Kenilworth, of anti-Semitic bias in the October 1999 incident.
Mr. Melchione had thrown large rocks at several businesses in Elizabeth's Elmora section whose signs indicated that they were owned by or principally served Jews, and had assaulted a Jewish woman.
Alan Silver, an assistant Union County prosecutor, said that without the element of religious bias, Mr. Melchione would have faced 180 days in a county jail or possibly probation.
In a statement in court, Mr. Melchione attributed his outburst to his being a paranoid-schizophrenic, rather than to neo-Nazi sympathies.

Last month the United States Supreme Court struck down provisions of the state's Ethnic Intimidation Act, or hate crimes law, that allowed a judge to increase a sentence in cases in which he or she found any sort of bias as an aggravating circumstance.

In their ruling, the justices found that a jury must determine such bias before a judge could increase penalties. Some groups, including the Anti-Defamation League of New Jersey, had feared that this would hamper use of the state's hate crimes law.

Judge Ross R. Anzaldi noted in sentencing Mr. Melchione today that his admitted psychiatric problem and failure to take medication kept the case from being a ''clear-cut case of the actions of a bigot.'' Nevertheless, he said that the guilty plea to the charges acknowledged bias, and Mr. Melchione therefore could be given a stiffer sentence.

Charles Goldstein, regional director of the Anti-Defamation League, said that there was some concern by the group and other organizations concerned with bias crimes that the Supreme Court ruling had seriously weakened the state's law.
''But this decision demonstrates unequivocally that those who commit bias crimes will go to jail,'' Mr. Goldstein said outside the courtroom here.

Joseph Spagnoli, Mr. Melchione's lawyer, said that he had advised his client to accept the plea agreement, admitting to the stiffer bias charge and facing a potentially longer sentence, rather than go through a trial in which he would have had to present the ravages of his illness as a defense to a hate crime charge.
